dt: {bc}weakness or weariness of body or mind

dt.t: {wi}languor{/wi} brought on by a hot summer afternoon

pt: {sc}lethargy{/sc} {sc}languor{/sc} {sc}lassitude{/sc} {sc}stupor{/sc} {sc}torpor{/sc} mean physical or mental inertness. {sc}lethargy{/sc} implies such drowsiness or aversion to activity as is induced by disease, injury, or drugs.
{sc}languor{/sc} suggests inertia induced by an enervating climate or illness or love.
{sc}lassitude{/sc} stresses listlessness or indifference resulting from fatigue or poor health.
{sc}stupor{/sc} implies a deadening of the mind and senses by shock, narcotics, or intoxicants.
{sc}torpor{/sc} implies a state of suspended animation as of hibernating animals but may suggest merely extreme sluggishness.

pt.t: a once alert mind now in a {it}torpor{/it}

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}langur{/it}, from Latin {it}languor{/it}, from {it}languēre{/it}
shortdef: weakness or weariness of body or mind
